sanskrit_verse:
चतुरो ब्राह्मणस्याद्यान् प्रशस्तान् कवयो विदुः ।
राक्षसं क्षत्रियस्यैकमासुरं वैश्यशूद्रयोः ॥ ३.२४॥
transliteration:
caturō brāhmaṇasyādyān praśastān kavayō viduḥ .
rākṣasaṁ kṣatriyasyaikam āsuraṁ vaiśyaśūdrayōḥ ..
sph_interpretive_translation: Four divine conduct forms are declared praiseworthy for the Brahmin; one demonic form is assigned to the Kshatriya; and one infernal conduct form each is designated respectively for Vaishya and Shudra.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority flows from consciousness capacity and role-specific dharma
Causation aligns with svadharma as determined by spiritual-cosmic order
Restoration logic operates through role-realignment and consciousness elevation
Consciousness alignment is achieved via adherence to svadharma without distortion
executable_legal_axioms: IF agent.role == 'Brahmin' THEN permissible_conduct_forms = {divine_form_1, divine_form_2, divine_form_3, divine_form_4}
IF agent.role IN {'Vaishya', 'Shudra'} THEN respective_infernal_form_assigned = TRUE

The court must recognize that each varna carries distinct energetic and functional responsibilities rooted in cosmic design. Misconduct is not judged by external standards but by deviation from the designated svadharma. Restoration occurs when individuals assume their rightful consciousness-aligned roles under judicial guidance.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa reveals that behavior originates from assigned svadharma, not arbitrary will. Anupūrvaśaḥ shows how misalignment manifests sequentially—first internally, then externally. Proportional responsibility lies in realigning with one's innate form rather than punitive measures. The non-punitive reality rule confirms that all beings seek harmony when consciousness is unobstructed.
